subject: Re: [junit] Testing abstract classes
msgSnippet: If it s anything like Ant, Maven find tests by searching the file system for source files that have names that match some pattern (ending in Test, but not
messageBody:
If it's anything like Ant, Maven find tests by searching the file system for
source files that have names that match some pattern (ending in Test, but
not starting with Abstract, for example).

However, the test is giving you some useful feedback. There is no need to
say "abstract" twice in the class definition. The class defines a concept (
e.g. "Thingy"). The class can be named after the concept only, because the
Java language has a built-in feature for marking classes as abstract.

--Nat

On 29/12/2007, jmdevins <josh@...> wrote:
>
> Normally I like to test my abstract classes separately from any
> concrete implementations I might have. I might have something like this:
>
> public abstract AbstractThingy {
> // some concrete methods in here that need testing
> ...
> }
>
> Based on this, I would name my test class: AbstractThingyTest
> (although it's not abstract itself).
>
> When I run JUnit in Eclipse, everything is fine and dandy. Running it
> from within Maven however seems to make this test not run. So I tried
> renaming the test to simply: ThingyTest. When I run this, it does in
> fact run.
>
> Anyone else encountered something similar? I suspect it's a bug and it
> should be looking for the keyword "abstract" instead of any file or
> class with the word "Abstract" in it.
>
> Thoughts?
>
> Josh
>
>
